reviewText:
This game should really be named Naruto Storm Full Burst Revolution 3.75. since there is no major continuation to the story line it is a typical filler from the creators of Naruto. Also there is just too much Chakra in this game with all these chars being brought back to life, it causes my game to crash frequently.  I also verified game cache multiple times still the game crashes.

So after 14.4 hours invested into the game and unlocking every character
Here is my analysis.

Pro's
- Ninja Escapades was well made and no pointless running from place to place. ( This was the main story for me not the Mecha-Naruto garbage.)

- Improved UI

-Class types
-Ultimate jutus allows use of your ultimate jutsu (which varies depending which support chars you chose)

-Awakening allows for true awakening, Magnekyou kakashi, Sage Mode Jiraiya, Kyuubi Mode Minato, Control over the 9 tails with Naruto, control the 10 tails with Obito, Susanoo's for those with Sharingan and much more.

-Drive mode Allows chars to seal 2 substitution jutsu gauge slots and their opponents Ultimate jutsu in battle. Also starts you off with full support drive ready to be activated from the start of the fight.

-Battle arena 1v1v1v1

-Chakra Rails in free for all are a nice touch. They allow you to ride around the arena using jutsu or shoot you into the air to come crashing down on opponents (each move varying per char)

- The timeline is well into Naruto and everyone is super powerful.

- The jutsu's are well created and aesthetically pleasing.

-Cons
- The main story line is based around Mecha-Naruto

- They Removed the forward combo from all chars leaving them with only 3 combos a tilt and a throw.

-Game crashes (some of them carry over from Full burst)
(This is a problem with my system.)

-Shisui Regular B combo finisher = game crash
-Hashirama (First Hokage) Normal punch = game crash
-Minato (Fourth Hokage) true awakening = game crash
-Shikamaru Ultimate Jutsu = game crash (which is actually a problem that I also had with Naruto Storm Full Burst 3.5)
I will post more as I find them.

- Annoying obstacle chars ruin the immersion of a free for all ninja battle.

- Free for all ninja battle in the story mode sometimes feels like a 1v3

- lack of player control for 1v1v1v1's,
(What needs to be implemented)
1) Allow players to set up free for alls and control options in free battle tab.
A) Allow 2v2's and 1v2's or even 1v3's.
B) Implement player free for alls
C) Allow toggle for obstacle chars/rails/traps/barrier for the arena

- Needs more combos for True awakening chars (Kurama only has 1 combo and ten tails only has an arm smash and arm sweep.)

- No Juubito

11/10 because I love the characters of Naruto and being able to fight with them (especially with the new Team Ultimate Jutsu system) does make it worth it for me.

But

6/10 as a fighting game. Maybe.


Someone came to me to ask about the controller mechanics. Having a controller absolutely does make this game easier to play, but is not necessary. I adapted to Naruto storm full burst pretty easily without the controller and only use the controller because my girlfriend bought one to use when she plays. But in my honest opinion Controller > Keyboard for this game.


Shout out to Hiradragon She (or he) makes a very valid point with this comment. I still prefer games like street fighter though.

reviewText:
As usual, the Ultimate Ninja Storm Revolution franchise never disappoints. Fast paced gameplay, great combos, massive character selection, endless collectibles, you name it and this game has it.

Let's go over some pros and cons:

Pros:

+ Massive character selection (Over 110 characters)
+ Combat system remains fantastic with new additions as well
+ Multiple new modes ranging from Tournament to Survival to Four Player Battle, etc
+ Endless collectibles
+ Newly animated content for the story mode
+ Online mode suffers less lag than previous games
+ Character customization / Network clones added for further playability

Neutral:

- Stage selection almost entirely the same as previous game bar ring outs
- Some modes end up being fantastic, others being repetitive and forgettable
- Graphics, while looking nice are almost entirely similar to previous game

Cons:

- Jobs in tournament mode are a hassle
- Inability to put all items on all characters

reviewText:
Revolution is a game made for entertaining, not impressing. It is a fanservice, a way to spend time in an enjoyable way, not something that will cause catharsis. Is it good? Depends on how you look at it. As a fighting game, it's superior in every way for their predecessors. Still, there had to be a downside when compared to the old games: it has no storyline. Thing is, the game doesn't need one. I played it 100% to be sure of that. It has a lot of characters and even more sidequests.
There's a whole island to free roam, new areas get accesible as you progress in the tournaments, areas where you can find characters, do what they request to unlock them. On the island you can also exchange medals to get accesories and you can try your luck at the lottery. The tournament mode is a lot of fun, it's well designed and the challange clearly goes higher as you go near the end of the path, the spot where your chosen ninja is acclaimed as being the greatest of them all. Best part is, it doesn't get repetitive. There are obstacles, enemy power ups, all kinds of things to keep you pumped.
There's also a short story involving an abandoned concept, the mecha-naruto, a story which has some humour, some moral talking(you have to look deep) and an emotional end. It can also be considered as a NaruHina fanservice.
One feature that should be noted is the Team Ultimate Jutsu, which actually makes the who's on your team) matter

reviewText:
Storm 3: Full Burst was good, but Storm Revolution brings the Storm series back, even better than before!
Pros:
+ Improved Single Player Port
+ Framerate is far better than Storm 3, but still could use some work
+ Gigantic Character Roster
+ Only 3 storylines, but satisfying, especially with anime cutscenes
+ Characters are more fun
+ Characters are balanced
+ Online stops disconnecting during a match

Neutral:
+- Ninja World Tournament is satisfying, but making a 4 player (1v1v1v1) battle system a single player exclusive...... Ehhhhhhhh

Cons:
- Framerate online is STILL awful
- Button commands for all characters are the same; a bit repetitive
- Still a lack of optimization options
- No actual story mode

Overall: 8.3/10 - Glad to see that the PC port improved. Keep up with learning from your mistakes, Bandai Namco! Your games are great, ignoring the port!

reviewText:
For what it's worth, this game is fun. However, if you don't own a gamepad or XBOX 360 Controller, this game is nigh impossible to play. It took me almost an hour to beat the 3rd battle in story mode, simply because the Keyboard controls are so convoluted and hard to use. That being said, this game assumes you have an XBOX 360 controller plugged in, so all the movement instructions are in the format of ABXY commands (Which, on a Keyboard, are bound to L;PO by default). Good luck trying to figure out where the RT and LT buttons are. It took a lot of getting used to to play this properly, and the controls cause my hands to become quite cramped after a relatively short gaming session (about 30 minutes).
The game itself, graphics, story, voice acting, characters and whatnot, are excellent, the models are well made and the attack animations are great. There are characters that are clearly overpowered, such as Bijuu mode Naruto and Deidara, as well as those that are severely underpowered, like Konan, but that's to be expected in a game set in the Naruto Universe.

All in all I'd give this game a 7/10, if you're playing with a keyboard.
If you have a controller or a gamepad, I'd give it an 8.5/10.

reviewText:
A short review of NARUTO SHIPPUDEN: Ultimate Ninja STORM Revolution.

Pro's

-New attacks to old characters (only for awakening type)
-Ninja world tournament, great addition (you can freely choose which character you want to play)
-New characters
-Short stories (creation of the akatsuki, the two uchiha, the far reaches of hope)
-Online, more stable (not so many transmission errors)
-New battle mode, league
-Character customization
-Combo Ultimates (with certain supports team ultimate changes to new ultimate)

Cons

-New combat system/mechanics (awakening, team ultimate, drive) limits gameplay. Drive type is almost useless in 1 vs 1 without supports. I think it was a bad choice to change mechanics.
-Drive type is broken (too good)
-Ninja world tournament challenges (too many and repetive)
-No story mode
-Online, bad optimization (still lags), steam CPU bug
-Overall game optimization (30 FPS, etc...)

My score: 6/10

If you are planning to buy this game, buy a controller it is definitely worth it.
Overall I think Storm 3 was better game. I will still recommend this game because it is a still great addition after Storm 3.

reviewText:
After playing 5 hours through the game i realised something: There is no actual anime story. And i wouldn't want it any different.

To some this might seem to be an unwise decision. However, I bet that the developers thought of the same thing i did before the game's release: if they put the story that spans from Storm 3's ending to the present animated episode (and more precise, The Ten-Tails Jinchuriki) then for the next game (Storm 4 maybe?) there wouldn't be any plot left (and i have taken into consideration the manga). Moreover, it's not the first time a Naruto game has it's own story that is not connected to the anime. It's just like a filler that is present in the anime, but not in the manga, only we are talking about a game.

With that being said, it's time to dwelve into the said game. An improvement is sure to be noticed from the previous game. While it runs the same engine (and you might observe that the whole menu works the same), the game's graphics  look stunning as always.

The main story is more quest-oriented, with open-world exploration and that is exactly what we needed: a relaxing game that is simply the bridge between Storm 3 and the next Storm game. And when i say relaxing i mean that there is no actual plot development, as the battles are even more intense than ever. You have to participate in a tournament, that gets more and more difficult with every rank you pass. Outside of the tournament, you can make quests to get people in your team, play through arena challenges or do jobs. What more do you want than offering a flower to Lord Orochimaru just so he can join your team in the tournament?

Outside the tournament you can play the Mecha-Naruto story (something teased in the last episode of Naruto Shippuden) or the Ninja Escapades. Those are never-before-told stories, that are long like an episode of the anime and let you do the battles.

The battle mechanics have also changed and take more of a strategic theme. You can now choose between Ultimate Jutsu, Awakening and Support Type. When you fill a special bar you can do something different depending on the Type you chose. Ultimate Jutsu does a stronger Ultimate jutsu that take double damage than normal. Awakening disables the Ultimate Jutsu but let's you use Awakening Mode. Finally, Support  makes use of your teammates and you can do a Sealing Jutsu that temporarily disables Chakra, Substitution etc. Depending on what you enemy uses, you can think tactically and choose what Type best suits the battle. I normally have doubt between Ultimate and Awakening since those 2 are pretty epic and i miss being able to use both.

On the downside, the game has a problem for attempting full 3D exploration(remember those camera angles in Storm 3? they're gone) and that is rendering distance. NPCs spawn a little late and you can be right near them and not see them.

All in all, the game is surely a lot multiplayer-oriented, having the biggest character roster.  Also, during the tournament you can see something Dark Souls-like. People can Ã¯nvade" your world through Network Clones. You can fight them or leave them there as they do not move. You can even send your own clone and have it level up. I haven't tried the network mode yet so i don't know if the connectivity problems are solved (though i didn't encounter any in Storm 3 Multiplayer

reviewText:
In term of additionnal content, the game looks great, though the Ninja tournament Story Mode is, to me, quite boring (mecha naruto? really?). Still, the versus mode was what I was waiting for - and turned out to be a huge disappointment. I have spent hours and hours on NS:UNS 3 with my friends, and we were quite excited to play with the promising new game modes -  mean: true awakening, super support drive and combo ultimate jutsu: how could we not be pumped up?

The problem is, when you select one of these mods (and you are obligated to do so, there is no way around, no mod, nothing), the game locks ANY element of gameplay related to the other mods.
Which means : you cannot use your BASIC support style or enjoy your BASIC awakening if you want to have a Combo super jutsu ; you cannot use the BASIC super jutsu and BASIC awakening if you get the better support style, etc.

In the end, half of the old versus gameplay has been cut out of the game, preventing you from using the wide range of possibilities the previous game offered you. There is no classic mode : if you want to battle, you will have to do so without 2 core elements of your gameplay. And this drawback really ruined the game for me, as it really, really limits the choices you can make when in fight, going from a enjoyable and rich decision-making game to a deppressing kite
date: vaguely land your combos and wait for your stong move" kind of game. The two new moves (counter attack and guard break attack) do not create enough variety on their own

reviewText: Futher thoughts after more time with the game: Half the new ideas were clearly come up with by a gibbon. The story mode is a joke first of all. The Akatsuki Origins is interesting and takes about an hour. The Two Uchiha is also nice to see but was covered almost in its entirety by that Kakashi filler a while back adding in only a handful of new scenes and taking perhaps half an hour. The last one is a ten minute cutscene with zero gameplay and while it's still nice, I'm sure I don't need to explain why that's stupid. Then there's the one to two hour Mecha Naruto campaign that no one cares about. So yeah. The story clocks in then at less than four hours. No Tournament mode doesn't count because that's the same bloody fight with vaguely increasing levels of difficulty ad nauseum. I'd be disappointed if most indie games only lasted four hours much less a full priced game.\n\nAs for the Tournament mode by its own benefits though, it's fun enough and changes up the gameplay a bit. But again the gibbon left his grubby fingerprints all over everything and added a bunch of moronic special conditions. My favourite of which is when enemy attacks seal" you. That is; you can't use Chakra for a time. No one apparently explained to the developer that Chakra is an essential part of the game. So your only recourse at this point is to stand around like a lemon with your thumb up your â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥. And this even applies to the free
date: long range and very hard to see coming and thus avoid Shuriken attacks. That three other characters whose AI only seems to target you can all throw. So you're basically guaranteed to spend that entire time wallowing in utter pointlessness. As well as plenty of other poor design choices and execution.\n\nThis game isn't worth Â£40/$50. reviewText:
This is the second Naruto game to come to Steam and just like the previous one, I enjoyed it a lot.
The story this time around isnâ€™t following the events of the anime or manga but instead includes an original story about Mecha Naruto and Akatsukiâ€™s backstory. Itâ€™s fairly enjoyable but I only played through it once to be honest.
Just like the previous one, the graphics look fantastic and faithfully translates Narutoâ€™s world into a game. The options are little limited though. You can chose resolution, V-Sync, Super sampling and window/fullscreen. I think at this point I should note, the game is locked at 30fps, which isnâ€™t a big deal, the animations are extremely fluid regardless.
In terms of gameplay I find this one to be the best, theyâ€™ve included a few new mechanics like counter and guard break pill, and you can chose from 3 different battle types: Ultimate Jutsu Type, Drive Type and Awakening Type. Itâ€™s an attempt to balance the game but Drive type seems to be the best from all 3.
There are new 4 player(You and 3 AI) battles that you can enjoy in the Ninja World Tournament, which get boring fast, due to the easy AI. Itâ€™s a shame that this canâ€™t actually be played with 4 players.
Other than that there is huge amount of content from a huge rooster of characters., customization items for your characters, cards, titles.

If you are a Naruto fan, this is a must buy, plenty of fan service and fun to be found.

reviewText:
I'd like to recommend this game, but I really can't. It's really really fun if you play with some friends locally with a couple of beers. It's easy to learn, looks flashy and you could develop your skills and get better if you wanted. However, the singleplayer part is poop. Mostly boring 4 character brawls over some orbs, it gets old really quick.
Well aren't you glad that you can go online then? Nope, because the netcode is horrible and the PC port is terrible. Like say you play against someone who runs the game at 20 FPS while you have a steady 30, in any other game you'd have the advantage. But not here, you get lag and constant messages about waiting to connect during the fights. And when thats not happening the delay can be so bad your character wont react to your commands for a second. Yup, it's a mess.
Which is really sad because the local Versus mode is so much fun.

TLDR: Don't buy unless you plan on playing exclusively offline vs and friend or two.

reviewText:
I played this game for couple of hours, tried free battle and the tournament story mode (including mecha-naruto story) and from what I've seen. I can only recommend this game.

I'm playing on a laptop, and not a gaming one in fact. So for me to still be able to run this without problems is perfect. So some of you with old pieces of sh*t PC's can also enjoy a tournament I suppose. And as for bugs some report. I've seen none so far.

Now let's get to the details. The mechanic is almost the same as in Full Burst. But the step forward is the 3 battle types you can choose from.
Ultimate jutsu - as for every charecter you can use the ultimate jutsu for pure power. But also with a full bar you can perform a team utlimate. Nothing special, it's all standard.
True awekening - This is a great option. You can't use utlimate but you can become stronger in a pinch. If you play right you don't even have to go below 50% of your HP. This allows you to become stronger and use some hidden abbilities. For examples Hidan with true awekening can with LB create a circle and with RB you can spam to induce damage on your oponent without moving. And even if you move just reactivate a new field with L1 and viola. Death in spot. But ofcourse evry character has it's own true awekening with more power or different use.
Support Drive - This one.. I haven't tried much. I only know if you fill out the bar you can perform a FREAKING SEALING JUTSU. With that you instantly seal 2 substitution logs, half chakra, the power bar (for one of the 3 styles) and such. Really gives you advantage in a pinch if you know how to play strategy in a full head-on battle.

Characters are amazing, new ones bring interesting option.s Although unlocking them is hard as in tournament mode you have to go to them, complete their tasks and then you may play them. Some you win when you finish a tournament mode. Like 3rd Raikage on D tournament as a additional prize.

I would surely recommend this game. It has potential to be time consuming.

12/10 because 11/10 ain't enough.

reviewText:
Ahieved all achievements 100% and played the whole game. About NARUTO SUNSR: First of all, it has an nice Online-Multiplayer-Tournament Modus. Sure it cant reach such games like Street Fighter, but it is over the average. Graphics are impressive! and its respect for the source material is tremendous. The traditional model for this type of game is well established: developers choose a saga or story arc from the anime and creates a campaign around it, supplementing it with some extras and versus modes. Also an new attraction in the form of Ninja Escapades, a mode that has three small stories, intending to fill some gaps left by the anime or manga. This includes the origin of the Akatsuki group and all are filled with animated sequences, produced by the team that makes the television series. It's an interesting addition, which serves as exclusive episode of the series, with the difference that the fights take place with the game engine, and with the participation of the player.

Conclusion:  Positiv: Small original stories accompanied with Anime sequences. Tournament mode is fun. More than 100 characters. Perfect for fans of Naruto.
Negativ: Does not follow the series storyline. It lacks a major campaign. Among so much characters, there are natural imbalances, but maybe some patches gonna fix that.

If you like such games and love Naruto. Grab it! Otherwise wait for steam sale's. 8/10

reviewText:
Naruto Shippuden: Ultimate Ninja Storm Revolution is not as revolutionary as the title might suggest, but I think it's the step in the right direction.

The disappointing thing is lack of canon story mode in the game. Instead, we have Ninja World Tournament, Mecha-Naruto Story and the Ninja Escapades. The Ninja World Tournament is just mode, in which you thrive for championship in a tournament consistin of 4-characters brawl. Initial ranks of the tournament are easy, but difficulty rises gradually. Also, you can roam the island (the bigger progress you made in the tournament, the more areas you can visit), doing challenges, missions and events. Even thought it has absolutely nothing to do with canon storyline, the mode is quite fun to play, some friendship events are hilarius.

Mecha-Naruto story is mode, in which you learn the story of the most controversial element of this game: Mecha-Naruto character. Designed by Masashi Kishimoto himself, Mecha-Naruto is machine based on game's tiltular character. His story is rather short, but it explores topics and problems Naruto fans are pretty familiar with. The story has a potential, but the execution is lacking: it could be a much more emotional story.

Ninja Escapades consists of 3 mini-stories: The Creation of Akatsuki, The Two Uchiha and The Far Reaches of Hope, each has cutscenes made by original show's animators, Studio Pierrot. It's a pitty thought, that only two of these actually consist of gameplay. The stories are supposed to be surpervised by Masashi Kishimoto, but I don't believe that: at least two of these stories consists of logical errors. It was the most obvious in the Creation of Akatsuki: we haven't learned of how the leader managed to win against legendary Hanzo the Salamander; we didn't learn of who were the previous partners of Kakuzu, since he is state to be killing them; Sasori's former Akatsuki partner never saw his true form in the manga; Deidara and Orochimaru didn't belong to the group at the same time, much less Hidan and Orochimaru. I could go on.

The story isn't strong element of this title.

The game is 3D figthing-like game, based on Masashi Kishimoto's manga series. I said 3D fighting-like game" because it uses very simple game controls - you won't be fighting your controller constantly. Instead
date: you'll be making a very simple button combinations (like block + attack
hoursPlayed: chakra + jump etc.) and the basic combos are combosed on just attack button and directional pad.\n\nThat is not to say that the game is boring and has no substance to it. The gameplay is very dynamic

reviewText:
As the Naruto series slowly comes to an end, I find myself saddened and desperately trying to find Naruto experiences that will help me relive the greatest moments from the manga and anime.  This is such a rich universe filled with loveable characters, epic battles, and awesome powers.  Utimate Ninja STORM Revolution brings the mythos and AWESOME to life at every step..  But there are opportunities.

First, I will warn you that the console versions still seem to be the way to go but this port is the best I've played so far.  We're all hopeful Storm 4 will deliver across the board but this game is no consolation prize.  What I love about this game is that it strikes a great balance between action/adventure game and deep fighter.  The exploration and questing is as satisfying as pulling off 60+ combos, calling in support, or pulling off an amazing block/comeback.

Replay value is a huge thing for me.  As a family man, I can't buy every game that comes out so, when I buy a game, it needs to provide tons of replay value and fun.  Revolution certainly fits the bill there.

Really, I love everything about this game.  It looks beautiful and the PC frame rate issues seem to have been resolved.  There are only a few things that bug me.  They are not deal breakers but it's good to know they are there:

1)  Loading Times - They feel too long for what the game is..  Sure, there is the open world component but loading between menus seems very archaic to me.  You may want to load this game onto your SSD, which I may very well do.  Mind you, my gaming rig is not a bleeding edge system but it is more powerful than the average PC so this should not be happening at all.

2)  Button Assignments - While you can remap buttons fully and controller support is flawless, I still don't get the button mappings in this series.  I feel that wasting a button for charging chakra is silly but I suppose it makes sense with the mechanic of chakra-loaded attacks.  A dedicated shuriken button, however, is really goofy.. But no biggy.  I would just rather see a weak/medium/strong setup for more control over your combos and fighting style; that way, people can't write this off as a mere button masher.

3)  Lock-On System - The 1v1 battles are still the best.  I love the concept of FFA/Battle Royale, but the lock-on system here still leaves something to be desired.  You click the analog stick to unlock and click again to lock on, but it's not always clear which target you will lock onto.  A simple fix would be to have the crosshair appear on your targets as you move your characters, then click to confirm the lock.  Easy.

Regardless, this game is tons of fun and it makes me want to go back to the XBox 360 and even Gamecube games.  That's not because this game sucks but, rather, it's so good you want to explore and revisit all the Naruto games.  I hope they make proper ports of all the games from previous platforms but, more importantly, I hope they make them proper ports, deserving of the PC platform.

Anyway, back to UNS Revolution...

One feature I absolutely LOVE is the Network Clone.  This is an avatar that battles online players while you are away from the game.  They pop up in other instances, collecting items and experience.  You can fully customize your Network Clone and Story/Ninja Tournament characters, which I love because this gives the unlockables even more value.

Ultimate Ninja Storm Revolution combines the best of breed technologies and game mechanics from games like Mystic Heroes, Dynasty Warriors, Dragon Ball-Z (the good ones, not Xenoverse), and Forza (i.e. driveatars).  Truly, this game is a treat.  If you're a fan, don't hesitate..  Though I will say it is better-suited at $40 or less, not $50.. At least on PC.

With regards to Ombre's review and similar write-ups, the Story/Campaign is not boring if you don't mind running around a bit and reading lots.  There is quite a bit of dialogue and not that much voice acting, which isn't a bad thing but it does make me feel that this is a licensed game that should have released at a more appealing price point since they did cut a few corners.

When you choose your move type"
date: you have to choose between Awakening (buffed character)
hoursPlayed: or Ultimate Justu (unlocks OP ultimate).  I think this is actually a selling point for more casual players or folks like me

reviewText: If you are looking for a rich deep story mode, this isn't the game for you. I would suggest checking out the older Naruto title on steam, which does have a very deep story mode. This game was made to test new systems, along with give fans something to play while the story from the manga is finished. There are only three side stories and one short video clip in this title, along with a repeatable game mode (+online and what you come to expect from any fighter).  The replayable game mode battle system changes slightly with each replay along with opening new zones, this adds some new challenges to each reply. This game is great, if you want to play and test out all the characters in the Naruto world. There's over 100 characters and three different battle types for each. Some of the 100" characters are just reskins
date: while other reskins totally change the moves and how that fighter attacks. For example there's at least 10 different versions of Naruto. However he only really has around 4 move sets
recommended: which you can see when choosing. Adding combo finishers does make it fun testing out new teams
hoursPlayed: and see what abilities they use together. This game is great if you just want to sit down and fight it out and don't care to see the whole story over again. It isn't for anyone just jumping in and hoping to learn the lore of the Ninja world."

reviewText:
I got this game for 10 dollars and even at that low price I believe it to be a big waste of money. The game is almost exactly like 3 only with less content, yes less content.

They got rid of all the good singleplayer modes from 3 and replaced it with terrible story modes that made me want to skip through cutscenes just so I could hurry up and finish through the tediousness. The ninjs escapades was a nice touch as it contained content from the show and brought back the old generations style of play (story relevant to the show with simple one on one battles that allow you to unlock new content if beaten. However ninja escapades is beatable in an hour or 2 including the cutscenes and not worth buying the whole game for.

In theory the tournament mode where you can fight more than one opponent was a good idea and something that I was looking forward to. Sadly it feels terribly underdone and could have been majorly improved on, plus it's only playable in singleplayer which seems like a stupid idea, if you're making a gamemode that is designed to have multiple people fight at the same time why the hell would you lock it to just singleplayer? Seems like a major missed opportunity that they were to lazy to implement.

They barely added anything new to this game that makes it worth buying if you already have 3 and if you don't have 3 then buy that since it's cheaper and a way better option. I should also mention that the one major pro to this game is how much better the AI is however with the singleplayer mode being rubbish this game is only worth playing with other people.

reviewText:
for day one players this might have been a bit confusing, supposed to be released the 16th but playable on the 15th. either way.
there isn't much to the story mode other than a little about kakashi's past, A story that goes into more detail to the night Itachi killed his clan, and how the akatsuki grouped up.
the 4 way battle system is pretty fun, but it feels more like a mini game if anything sadly not as intense as i had hoped.
the charecters are alot better, and even a few updates to some old ones like kakashi (about time you damn developers)
the battle system was broken down into Ultamate jutsu, Awakening and drive. in a sense you can either use ultamate jutsu or awakening, not both anymore. makes this game a little bit harder but at the same time makes you try and figure out who best suits which role and plan your strategy that way. the online is fixed connection wise for any of you who have played the previous game on steam.
But if you can live without a long story mode about the ninja war and engage in hours of battles, then this is the game for you. if your just buying this for the story mode then this is probable a game you want to skip.

reviewText: I can get past the mediocre 'Ninja World Tournament'. I can get past the laughable 'Mecha-Naruto storyline'. reviewText: This is one of those games I'm highly indifferent about. Looking back, I wouldn't call this game a bad game at all, in fact I quite enjoyed it. The story" is comprised of four short stories with some (easy) fights peppered in that expand the lore in the naruto world through the story of the Akatsuki
recommended: a unique story about the new character "Mecha Naruto"
hoursPlayed: along with a 10 minute movie about team Minato which I quite enjoyed. Overall
voteText: this will take maybe 2-3 hours to complete. Which is quite  a bit less than I'd expect for a game with such a steep price tag. The replay value is unfortunately nonexistant unless you are looking for the two achievements given for achieving S ranking on the Itachi and Akatsuki mini story lines. However
helpfulPercent: if you didn't already get these achievements on your first playthrough as these fights are quite easy
votesHelpful: you will without a doubt get it on your second. There is also the "Ninja world tournament mode" which I enjoyed quite a bit. In this mode
votesTotal: you can select a character of your choosing (with the exception of all the young characters
votesFunny: which kinda sucks) and duke it out in a four-player brawl against NPCs. Unfortunately
commentsCount: there is no online mode for this. This is really awful since like the rest of the NPCs
column16: they are quite easy to defeat
column17: and offer no real challenge. I will admit by the S+ tournament I was sweating a bit at the intensity
column18: but the difficulty is entirely due to major NPC buffs in the form of a constant "true awakening form" and not a more advanced AI. That being said
column19: I still won it on my first go-around which really ruins the fun of the game. This will most likely take about 5-6 hours to complete (basing off my own time). And overall
column20: you'll get about 7-9 hours of gameplay out of the story if you play to completion. Such a small playtime leaves something of a bitter taste in my mouth considering the price tag of this game. However
column21: if you're seeing my play time
column22: you'll notice I have 100+ hours in this game as of writing this review. This is due to this games' bread and butter
column24: unfortunately enough for the online mode
column25: the online community has depleted in the two months since this game has come out. This has made finding someone to fight almost a chore and you really have to just open the game and cross your fingers that you'll find someone. Speaking from personal experience
column26: now that the game is about 2 months after launch
column27: it is a very common occurence that you will find noone to battle.Near the games' launch
column28: the online was solid and all you had to worry about was a tiny bit of lag since so many people were on the servers. However
column29: even now that not so many people are using the servers
column30: the lag is still existant if not worse. This is a huge no-no in my opinion for a 1v1 fighter to have any form of lag. Especially to the point of making the game near unplayable at points. This raises a secondary issue in the fact that even if you manage to find someone to play against
column31: that person might have a laggy connection and make your game either near impossible to play
column32: or make your game crash entirely. In total
column33: this game was very fun. But now that the main focus of this game
column36: I would advise against purchasing this game. Still
column37: for all the fun I had
column38: I think this game is great. 8/10
column39: buy it if you have a time machine or you love wasting money for a couple hours of fun.\n\nEdit: Some grammar corrections / spelling"

reviewText:
It is a good game but not really much new stuff like most of the naruto games, but the ninja escapades are awesome and really interesting. The new game mode Ninja Tournament thing isn't that fun tbh but its cool being able to run around an island roaming around and exploring.

They also added a few new mechanic like counterattacking when you press LB2 + Square (PS3 Controller) You can stun them if they are running in to you, makes it easier to hit ultimate jutsus. Other then that they added a few more characters which is always a good thing, i recommend this game for any naruto fans, might not be as fun for people who aren't into naruto though.

If you looking just a brawler, and are a fan of naruto or not this game is probably the most dissapointing in the serisis the new mechanics are great but the story is bland.

- Full Burst is a much better overall game.

reviewText:
First of all, if you're looking for a multiplayer experience then this probably isn't the game for you. As usual with CC2's work there are a lot of broken characters for the sake of fan service. And honestly, that isn't a bad thing as it remains true to Naruto's actual manga/anime. But of course people take advantage of that online.
I was skeptical of the game at first, seeing that the focus was primarily on the battle orb 4 player fights but those actually aren't that bad. In all honesty, it has been refreshing to have something a bit different come out of a Storm game so I can't complain at all.

To break down some of the quick pros and cons of the game:

Pro + Ninja Escapades - probably only about 75 minutes or so of content here if you watch all the cutscenes but this was done beautifully. Anime cutscenes interwoven with story and fights. It's unfortunate that it is so short because it is easily one of the best parts of the game.

Pro + More awesome characters that were not in Storm 3, like the JinchÅ«riki, past Kages, and Shisui.

Con - Imbalanced P2P multiplayer. But this is pretty much a given at this point for these games, it hasn't gotten better.

Con - Mecha Naruto Story - this one... just left me wondering... why? It is about 3 hours long by my estimation and it only gets worse-- not better. And it doesn't even start off great considering all that. In hindsight if I had known it was going to be that bad, I would have skipped the cutscenes and saved myself some time. Really though, it's straight trash, if you don't care about the achievement I wouldn't even bother.

Con - Still 30fps locked. Please stop CC2. Please stop.

Overall, even though this game gets ridiculously repetitive it's a fighting game and that's to be expected. I've gotten a lot of enjoyment out of this game so I'd be hard pressed to rate it lower than a 7/10. It's worth playing if you're a Naruto fan even with its flaws.

reviewText:
Alright so i'v been playing this for a couple hours now and i can safely say this, Its by no means a bad game, its just different from other NS games.

The good;
*Plenty of characters.
*A reason to keep playing (For me its the ninja tournament)
*Beautiful grapics
*Good fighting system
*The drive team, awakening team and ultimate justu team system allows for more ways to play characters
*That network clone (forgot what it was called) stuff allows you to keep getting stuff even while your not playing
*BS naruto is so much less BS
*Team ultimate justsu
*character customization (you can edit existing characters with items)
*The ninja tournament starts out easy then gets harder continuously
*Free for all fighting in the ninja tournament
*Controller support praise the lord
*So much more

The bad;
*There isn't really much story to it aside from the mecha naruto stuff
*Some things from the ninja storm three arn't in this (I miss my coordanated attack)
*After you have beaten all the tournament ranks i imagine there isn't much else to do (Correct me if im wrong)
*In ninja storm 3 if your supports were knocked out they were out of the fight...In this they get back up...i guess that can be a good thing but i personally dont like it

So i personally think that this is a good game, sure it can be short lived fun but if you can get some people together you can have a blast.
I would recommend this game if you were into fighting games without story.

reviewText:
Naruto Shippuden: Ultimate Ninja Storm Revolution (that's a mouthful) is a great fighting game. The visuals in this series never disappoint, and the tweaks made to the gameplay make it a solid fighter with a bit of strategy set into it.
(Please note that this doesn't cover all there is in the game. This is a review of what's important to note in the game)

First off, the combat. The previous game in the series (Storm 3) had a great mechanic where your support would act according to the type you set for each one of them separately (auto, attack and defense). The possibilities back then were limited by your skill saving up chakra and attacking in coordination with your support characters to fill up the Storm Gauge. In Revolution they've changed it so you choose one single type of combat for your team. These types are broken into:

Ultimate Jutsu Type: Allows you to perform an Ultimate Jutsu alone or in coordination with your 2 teammates if your Storm Gauge is filled to the top, however you can't access Awakening or make your teammates attack with you in a regular combo.

Awakening Type: Allows you to access the Awakening state at any time during a fight and True Awakening given your Storm Gauge is filled up. The downside to this is you can't use Ultimate Jutsu and you still won't be able to use your teammates in a regular combo.

Drive Type: Keeps your teammates with you at all times in three different forms: Auto Drive, Defense Drive and Attack Drive. Auto Drive makes your team attack with you during combos and deliver a final blow into your opponent by the end of a regular combo and often protect from Ultimate Jutsu aimed towards you, Defense Drive provides defense from your team when charging chakra or being approached with a Ninja or Chakra Dash, and Attack Drive works pretty much like Auto but without your team taking hits from Ultimate Jutsu for you. This type canâ€™t use Ultimate Jutsu or Awakening mode.
All three types can use Jutsu no matter the type and support during team battles.

New to the series is a single player mode called Ultimate Ninja Tournament. In this mode you and 3 AI controlled opponents fight against each other in the same arena. It's a competition for orbs which are dropped each time a character takes a hit, this will decrease the amount of orbs held by the victim and increase the ones held by the attacker. There are no health bars in this mode but taking a hit when your orb count is at zero will leave you off the battle. The fighter with the most orbs at the end of each round wins. There are of course many hazards in these arena battles, on top of 3 enemies that could gang up on you at any given time.

It's a fun mode that would replace the Story Mode in a numbered Ultimate Ninja Storm game, and while it's not story heavy every aspect of it nods to what if stories with lots of fan service content.

Another interesting aspect to the game is the customization. Online Ninja Cards make a return for this entry but character customization is a most welcome add on to the game. You can choose up to 3 accessories to be place on your character's arms, face, back or waist, a substitution item to replace the generic log, and 1 of four Ultimate Jutsu Finish screens for each character. All of these items are unlockable through Ultimate Ninja Tournament mode and by fighting Network Clones online.

The Ninja Escapades mode lets you play through short anime stories exclusive to the game. The little story they tell goes from gameplay to anime seamlessly, a nice touch that makes it enjoyable as short as it is.

At the end of the day this game's perfect for those people who like the anime, games and wish to do some fighting online and/or locally, but if you're looking for an epic battle conclusion to the events after Storm 3 you're going to be disappointed (though the character's dialogues are set up to that point in the story arc, which could come as spoilers to those who haven't kept up with the series at some points).

Pros:
Massive character roster
Diverse customization options
The new combat allows you to truly see the type you choose
Fan service all over the place
Cons:
The team types are great but not perfect. Some are unfair in the right hands.
You can't put accessories on special outfits (Anbu, school, warrior, etc.)
The story is there but you have to dig to find it
Hints:
Learn the basic and new techniques before heading online
Make sure you try every character to know what you're fighting against
Never fight someone online if your connection is at 2 bars (let alone 1)
After completing it to 100% I definitely recommend this game. The fan service, the visuals, the music, and the amount of content I did not include in this review make a solid game in the series, and a must if you can't wait for the next numbered entry.

reviewText: Naruto Shippuden Ultimate Ninja Storm Revolution, is a revolutionary gameplay about Naruto Shippuden. Unlike the previous game, Naruto Ninja Storm 3, this is a game that does not contain an official story mode about Naruto in the 4th great Ninja War.  However, this game does give support towards rumble and brawl types for the known naruto characters, the purpose that Bandai Namco created this game is to make all players enjoy the maximum experience of the character. Therefore, this games is excellent for those who would like to expereince new characters and behind the scenes.

reviewText:
Storyline - no.
There are only a few stories and mehanaruto. Very interesting and touching look at the Uchiha Shisui and his love for a friend and Konoha. History Akatsuki just fun and interesting

Added new characters and new jutsu (combo jutsu).
Scenes differ on who your opponent is, and it's great.

Liked items for characters and DLC costumes

Added own local-bot, which can be customized by you, to send into battle (ask any attack options and bonuses). Other players can now meet the bot at their own game, and it's really cool.

All very interesting and fun

I recommend this game =)

reviewText:
First off; I never really played Naruto games befor, only watched the beginning of the anime, it's a good anime :D, but just to many episodes for me to be totally honest.

I also never played a game like this on pc.. The controls are kinda hard getting used to, since i always played moba or fps games. So I am considering about buying a controller just because it is easier for a game like this.

But I do know that if you like oldschool Street Fighter or like Tekken, you will definitly like this game aswell! This game looks nice! I've been playing some tournament now, which I really enjoy playing, and made a little start at the story mode, what looked like the show itself, only when the battles come, it's time for you to take matters into own hands.

Very fun to play :D! Even for somebody like me who doesnt know everything about Naruto.

reviewText:
I'll give you a little background...

I love anime! DBZ and Naruto are my all time favourites and I've been watching them since I was young. Because of this I've generally bought most releases for both franchises and looked at them through rose tinted glasses.

This time however is the first time EVER I'm actually sorry I bought the game, Here I'll list why;

- There is no story! It's just 1 Island where you enter the same tournament 6 times with increasing difficulty. It isn't canon, it doesn't make sense and it's reptitive running around doing pointless fetch this from the other side of the map and bring it back" quests

- You have 3 side stories which last maybe 4-5 fights... History of the Akatsuki (so many inconsistencies with this story I don't even think it's canon)
date: a story about Shisui/Itachi and the coup (nothing here)
recommended: and Mecha Naruto which is quite frankly... terrible\n\n- For exisitng characters
hoursPlayed: the moveset hasn't been updated since UNS2 (at least the DBZ Budokai series did this)
voteText: it's so tiresome seeing the same movesets and animations if you own the other games\n\n- Not THAT many new characters. Yeah they added the Jinchuriki and some updated Edo Tensei characters but left out 7 Ninja Swordsmen
helpfulPercent: Gold and Silver Brothers and some others who are still only support characters like Cee
votesHelpful:
Chojuro etc (again same movesets)

- You can complete the "story" (tournaments) in 1 day and unlock all characters however to unlock all items it would take you about 1000 years. The completion time does not scale with the playability! You would just be grinding and grinding and grinding away for minimal rewards like accessories and probably wear your controller out before you got them and by then they will have released another one.

I'm not going to write too much more on this because it doesn't deserve a full review
votesTotal: it literally should have just been an update or dlc for UNS3 Full Burst. I had never listened to naysayers before this game
votesFunny: now I wish I had. Stick to playing previous versions
commentsCount: watch the VERY few new animations on YouTube in about 10 mins and that's all that's changed in the game and save yourself Â£30 odd quid!"

reviewText:
From ShonenGameZ.com:

Naruto is one of the most beloved Anime/Manga franchises ever. Some people put it right up there with the likes of One Piece and Dragon Ball Z, and it belongs to the notorious â€œBig 3â€³ group, the three highest selling titles in Japan.

While this may be true for the Manga and Anime sales, what about the video games? Anime game titles had their day during the PS2 era, where just about anything got a video game. During the PS3 age we started to see established franchises growing, and branches from the main trees of gaming falling off.

This meant no more Clash of Ninja, Rise of a Ninja, Ninja Chronicles, everything Naruto in gaming would be run by the Ultimate Ninja series, and that left the fate of Naruto on systems in the hands of Bandai Namco and Cyberconnect2. Together, the team has developed some of the prettiest fighters ever, with the Storm games, but when smooth graphics and flashy cutscenes arenâ€™t enough, the team likes to come back and do a game that focuses more on the battle between players.

That, would be Naruto Shippuden: Ultimate Ninja Storm Revolution. The Storm series has multiple entries. You have Storm 1, 2, and 3 which are all direct sequels of each other, and follow the main Naruto storyline. Then you have the pair of Generations and Revolution, which focus on side stories, while still introducing characters that are new from the manga/anime. These two titles however focus on one major thing, changes to the battle system.

Naruto Storm Generations gave us the Sub Bar system, tilt cancels, combo cancels, and more. This time around we have more wide spread changes to the game engine with the splitting of three major aspects of your character.

The Drive, Ultimate, and Awakening types being introduced into the game, limit, and open up your options in weird ways. Each has its own advantages and disadvantages, however Drive type does seem a little unnecessary.

Overall the main battle focus will most likely always remain the same. One button attacking with a few combos and flashy Jutsu, however this time around the changes that were implemented feel almost forced. There really was no reason to split up the different types, and if it was to make the game work better for more hardcore players, it falls flat on its face, due to how unbalanced the system can be.

The battling is still fun, and you can have some crazy matches against friends and rivals online, or in local multiplayer. Youâ€™ll find that a lot of your time is going to be spent in these modes, because what comes next is going to make you want to do so.

The story mode. The Storm games are actually being noticed more and more for their excellent story telling, and the cutscenes that bring the anime to life. This, should be the case here, however it doesnâ€™t work all that well.

You have two modes, Ninja Escapades, and Ninja World Tournament. Ninja Escapades will be easy to understand for players of Generations. There are anime cutscenes, you do a few fights, and you get another anime cutscene. These cutscenes are actually done very nicely by the animation studio, however theyâ€™re pretty compressed, and it causes the edges in a lot of shots to look pretty bad.

The actual story that the escapades tell are pretty interesting and they drag you in a bit, however it does feel like as they started to develop these modes, there was a level of laziness. You notice that the first mode is the longest, then the second story is really mostly cutscene, and the final â€œstoryâ€ is only cutsceneâ€¦ No battling.. why? Whats the point of that?

The other modeâ€¦ Ninja World Tournament, it really is.. something else.

There really is an effort here to give it some kind of story feel, but there are far too many moments in this mode that make you feel like they were copied and pasted. By block B, youâ€™re going to want to hack the game, mod Shizune, Mabui, and Shikaku into playable characters, and do your ultimate jutsu on them over and over.

It honestly makes no sense that this mode feels more like an after thought, if even that, because it was one of the things that they advertised the most. The Mecha Naruto side story that comes after you beat the first block of NWT is pretty tasking also.

About halfway through, you know whats going to happen. Its like the developers took all of the Cliches from one of the Naruto movies, and pasted Mecha Naruto in. It isnâ€™t terrible, but when I played I couldnâ€™t stop wishing it was over.

Overall, if youâ€™re looking for an updated version of Full Burst, with a different feeling to the battles, new flashy attacks, and a few cool moments, then pick up this title. Its sure to keep you online atleast for a few months until the next game gets announced.

Naruto Shuppuden: Ultimate Ninja Storm Revolution gets a 7/10

reviewText:
DO NOT BUY.

Worst purchase of the whole year. Judging from advertisements and trailers, this game could be considered scam.

* NO Story mode besides 3 (VERY) short stories, which are done in under 1 hour.

* VERY bad connection. The networking code of this game is horrible. Even if you have a perfect connection, depending on gamemode, you will share your connection speed with your opponent (meaning if he has lags, you have them too).
This can result in battles being interrupted all 1-2 second by about 0,5 seconds with loading" popups.
Joining other people's lobbies will almost always result in a grave disadvantage for you due to noticable delays.

*Only 4 gamemodes:
1.) Online battles
date: which I described above.\n2.) World-Tournament mode
recommended: which actually is a mode in which you battle 4 times in each rank from D to S to be crowned best of the world. You can complete extremely short missions between the battles to either gain new comrades (must be done again for each character... ... ...) or to get some money (which is earned much much faster by simply bashing the A.I. in the VS mode over and over and over again) and items...\nBy spending this money on any item on any shop you gain lottery tickets that are your main source for character customization items. It all comes down to a long grind that rewards you with a diminishing chance for new gear.\n3.) Free-for-All -> This is your Local VS Mode
hoursPlayed: either with friends or the A.I. (which is no match at all)\n4.) Ninja-"Escapades" the sorry excuse for a story mode. Only 3 arcs of which one is just a cinematic with no content worthy to mention. All Episodes together have less than a dozen battles... I mean

reviewText: I'd have to say that this game was very dissapointing. If you play the Naruto games so you catch up on the story without watching all the filler like I do, then prepare to be dissapointed. The story (if you can call it that) is four short sequences one of which has no impact on the show or manga at all, the other three are exactly what i wanted to avoid by playing the game filler, they explain background on some of the past experiances of certain groups. The tournement is complete crap it's not challenging at all, the point of the fight is to gather orbs which in my oppinion defeats the fighting game stlye that we got in the past. The missions you do outside of the tournement to gain allies arnt really relevant when you gain one team because you're already OP. The fighting is the same as our last naruto game beside that now, instead of being able to go into our ultimate form and be able to use our ultimate in the same fight you have to choose which one you'd rather have, (which frankly is just â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥) we should be able to use everything just like in the previous games. Some of the characters you unlock from the story" cant even be used in the tournement shuch as all the young versions of Naruto and his friends

reviewText:
I'm a big fan of Naruto and All its Utimate ninja games.. except this one. The most disappointing part of this game? THERE IS NO STORY MODE. WHY DID YOU REMOVE STORY MODE, BANDAI?!  Tournament mode has some cutscene dialogues but its theme is like some lame filler from the anime. It doesnt link up with anime at all.  Ninja Escapades are short stories from the anime timeline, like the creation of Akatsuki, which was never shown in the anime, but there are only 4 stories, and each last about 30mins at most.

The combat mechanics have improved a little, which is good.. there is now 3 types you can choose from for your character, Utimate Jutsu type, Awakening type and Drive type.. Each of which has their strengths and weaknesses. This adds variety and more choices to your fighting style.

Overall I would give this game a 5/10.. If your intentions are buying this game for epic story like in UNS3, save your $65.
If you do not watch the anime or the manga but are just a fan of the game, you will probably will not be as hype when you see the new chars available.

reviewText: So far, so good! I have never played a Naruto game before save for a few 5 minute sessions at friends' houses in passing. As a fanatic of 2-D fighters, especially Guilty Gear, BlazBlue, and Skullgirls, I decided to check this game out due to its seemingly immesnse content and arena fighting style. I cannot say that I am disappointed. Although it does not share the same complexity at first (combos are fairly easy to pull off compared to what I'm used to), it's extremely fun to drop crazy moves at a whim. The complexity IS there, however, it just manifests itself in a different way than I am used to.\n\ntl;dr: Get the game, it's really fun.

reviewText:
First off, I have followed the Naruto Storm fanchise since the very first game.
I feel this game has more balance to it than the others. The new characters are amazing and I pretty much can't stop playing this game. I have already put over 44 hours into this game and it has only been released for a little over three days. I'm not a fan of online so I have no idea what it is like, and I don't plan on knowing. I strictly stay with having a bunch of friends come over to play the game for hours on end.
I have played this game non-stop and I still haven't finished all there is to offer. I do feel the the challenges are quite repetitive, but still good. The Battle Orb tournements I feel is a bit broken. I would understand why 3v1 happens to me when I have over 6k orbs, but when all four start with 1k and all three are still coming after me, it becomes quite annoying.
Another entertaining thing you can do in this game is set up artificial boss fights in practice mode with the specific characters. So far the flaws I have found in this game are as followed: During free roam random characters eyes will glitch out causing them to go big and small constantly. Another is that some of the accessories don't fit characters very well causing them to glitch through the characters body. My final complaint is character specific accessories. I was really hoping you could have a really wide range of accessories, but all of the really cool" items are character specific. This was kind of a let down.
All in all
date: I do recommend this game to anyone who is a huge fan of the Naruto Series
recommended: or likes slightly strategic storm-based fighting games."

reviewText:
To everyone who is complaining about the games lack of a story mode....THERE WAS NEVER ANY MENTION OF A STORY MODE EVER!!!! This game is a filler game, so that the developers would have more story to work with NS4. They did the exact same thing two years ago with Ninja storm generations. The only reason this game exists is so people will have something to hold them over until the next game comes out. So now that we got that out of the way, here is my review on the steam version of this game.

Pros:
-Improved combat systems. I play with gamepad so i cant really comment on how it is with M/K but the gamepad is smooth and plays great. They have changed things up a lot since NS3 so expect to be surprised when you start up a game. First and foremost there are 3 ways to play each character, Ultimate jutsu user, awakening user, and drive user (team battle only). Ultimate jutsu users can use their best attacks but wont be able to awaken, awaken users can awaken but cant use ultimate attacks, and drive users will rely heavily on their team mates and wont be able to awaken or use ultimate moves. The new system may seem weird to some people, i personally think its a good system. It mixes up the feel of the game and makes each battle a little different especially when playing online.
-The tournament mode. Its great. I dont care what anyone says about it being awful, it really is the most unique thing the developers have done to this game that changes the gameplay so much that its actually worth replaying. The way the tournament is set up is, you have 4 teams. Each team has 3 members, and each has 1 person battle at a time. Each match will have 4 players fighting at once so it can get hectic. During these battles, there will be enviormental hazards and scenary that you can interact with to help hurt or help players win the battles. Outside of the battles, wondering the island holds different character events and different challenges to complete. On top of that, there is a story mode for the new mecha-naruto character. Its not that great of a story or that fun but it is there.
-More characters
-More stages
-new music
-can unlock characters outside of story mode buy earning money from battles. In case you hate the new tournament mode.
-offers japanese voice options for characters and subtitle options

CONS:
-laggy. In combat there is no notice of lag at all, which is why i recommend this game. It is a fighting game afterall and thats where the core of the gameplay is. Outside however, the frames stutter pretty badly, characters will pop in and out even at close distances and it is especially distracting during the animated scenes where your better off skipping them.

So thats it for my review. I really recommend that you get this game. If you are a fan of naruto and fighting games this is a must have.

Edit: oh and if you are expereincing a slow down in the combat, turn off super sampaling. In fact, just leave it off. It doesnt add anything to the game and unless you have a powerful rig its just going to ruin your experience

reviewText:
Let me preface this by saying I have been playing this title largely on my PS3 (which is why my play time on the steam version is really low, don't worry I will definitely be fixing that).

With that out of the way, lets get into the review. This game is a solid game and a decent addition to the storm series for a few reasons, though it is held back a little by lacking story content to a large degree. To be fair, there hasn't been much story progression from the anime/manga since storm 3, so I'm not really surprised to see them offer more filler based content in this iteration.

The story content is based around 3 very short 'escapades' that involve some animation in-between battles, these backstories revolve around the Akatsuki, Itachi and Shisui Uchiha and Kakashi's former team mates when they were younger. There is also the Mecha-Naruto story line, although I wouldn't count that as much of a narrative, while funny and slightly heartwarming, its execution was a little lacking and isn't much of a story by itself.

Beyond the lacking story content however is where we get to the meat of the game, and ultimately, the part where it shines the most. That would be the gameplay. While not too much of an overhaul, since this game runs on the same engine as the previous title, new battle mechanics as well as offering meaningful choice in how to play your characters really do add polish to the system.

Within this new system, players are offered the choice of 3 different types of set up for any given character, these types are Ultimate Jutsu, Awakening and Drive. UJ allows your character to perform their ultimate jutsu, and when their storm bar is full (a new mechanic) they can peform a team ultimate jutsu that executes a combo before their UJ is done. The upside of picking this is that UJ is much easier to land when using all the members of your team as a proxy for the technique (if even one of the 3 characters connects in dash, the technique is cast). For the Awakening type, you can do just that, anyone picking this has access to both Instant Awakening and True Awakening. IA has its advantages for both comboing attacks and also adding strength to the fight when you need it (balanced by reducing max chakra, thereby making it impossible to awaken breifly after using IA). True Awakening if actually used in a fight adds a lot of extra power and in some characters cases an almost boss-like presence on the battefield while in this state, this is something that can really turn the fight around. Drive types revolve around teamwork and automatic support, in order to balance not having either IA/True Awakening or UJ/team UJ's anyone using this type can count on automatic support as well as switching support focus during battle, on top of this supports knocked out during the fight may revive after a period of time has passed. The drive type's only trump card is the ability to seal both UJ's and Awakening types abilities for a short period of time.

Also of note, in this iteration of the storm series, customisation has been added, you can now edit your characters looks with accessories as well as their Substitution item and the video that plays upon a successful UJ finisher. Allowing both visual customisation, as well as focus choice really lets someone play how they would want to play, obviously its not the most in-depth customisation system, but it is a very welcome addition to the game.

Adding to this is some new battle mechanics, along with the usual Sub/Guard defence, a counter mechanic and guard break attack have been added, these new mechanics are balanced by their use of resources (reduction of max chakra for counter and ammo system for guard break). With these, and all previous options from the last game, as well as character focus types, present a lot more depth within fights than was seen in storm 3. There are now few more options for both the defending and attacking player, which leads to more interesting fights overall.

Of course, all of this is to speak nothing of the visuals of the game itself. It is quite a beautiful game, the style of the characters is very faithful to the animation style of the anime, and the environments to fight in are just as great to look at as the characters themselves. Add to this the technique animations, including the new awakenings/Special team ultimate jutsu's and this game certainly does not disappoint on the eye candy factor.

I have very few issues with this game, but there were a few things to stick out. Firstly, while the ninja world tournament mode is great, and a fun diversion, the amount of redundant content is a bit too much. There are challanges and 'jobs' on top of recruitment quests for this mode, and while recruitment quests aren't all that bad, there are a LOT of jobs to be done. Case in point, there were at almost 20 jobs for each rank of the tournament I have been in so far, and a vast majority are just the standard 1v1 with supports or the 4v4 orb brawl mode with only one or two being anything different and all of these fights have no real story context. Add to this the challanges of each rank and you have a sizable list of content to get through. The trouble is that it all feels quite repetative after a while, leading to the realisation that the developer added these almost grind like elements mainly for the completionists and to give longevity to what would have otherwise been a short mode.

All in all, here are the pros/cons for this game.

Pros:

New focus types/Customization add to personal choice
Environments and characters are as beautiful as ever
Awakening/UJ/Team UJ animations are awesome
New fight mechanics on top of old help to make the fights more interesting than the last game
Naruto and Sasuke Swapping outfits had me fanboying a little, smart move CC2
Shisui Uchiha and Kurama mode Naruto as playable characters? yespls
Cons:

Lack of longer story content could upset a few fans
Redundant content in the Ninja tournament mode is a little annoying
While I enjoyed the Mecha-Naruto story somewhat, I can see why a lot of people couldn't take his addition to the game seriously
Danzo exists

In summary, this game is better than storm 3, gameplay wise and I suppose graphics wise and is a solid title in itself, but the lack of story content may irk some fans (though it doesn't bother me to much) and the amount of redundant content in the nina world tournament mode may get on the nerves of some completionists.

I give it, 7/10.

reviewText: Well I can't say much about this game. If you don't meet the reccomended requirements for this game then don't buy it, it will lag like mad. I almost meet it so I'm good. The local multiplayer is really fun as well. So if you want a fighting game with an okay story, bad online, but is really fun to just mess around with, then this is the game for you. I enjoy it, so I give it a reccomendation.

With that out of the way, lets get into the review. This game is a solid game and a decent addition to the storm series for a few reasons, though it is held back a little by lacking story content to a large degree. To be fair, there hasn't been much story progression from the anime/manga since storm 3, so I'm not really surprised to see them offer more filler based content in this iteration.

The story content is based around 3 very short 'escapades' that involve some animation in-between battles, these backstories revolve around the Akatsuki, Itachi and Shisui Uchiha and Kakashi's former team mates when they were younger. There is also the Mecha-Naruto story line, although I wouldn't count that as much of a narrative, while funny and slightly heartwarming, its execution was a little lacking and isn't much of a story by itself.

Beyond the lacking story content however is where we get to the meat of the game, and ultimately, the part where it shines the most. That would be the gameplay. While not too much of an overhaul, since this game runs on the same engine as the previous title, new battle mechanics as well as offering meaningful choice in how to play your characters really do add polish to the system.

Within this new system, players are offered the choice of 3 different types of set up for any given character, these types are Ultimate Jutsu, Awakening and Drive. UJ allows your character to perform their ultimate jutsu, and when their storm bar is full (a new mechanic) they can peform a team ultimate jutsu that executes a combo before their UJ is done. The upside of picking this is that UJ is much easier to land when using all the members of your team as a proxy for the technique (if even one of the 3 characters connects in dash, the technique is cast). For the Awakening type, you can do just that, anyone picking this has access to both Instant Awakening and True Awakening. IA has its advantages for both comboing attacks and also adding strength to the fight when you need it (balanced by reducing max chakra, thereby making it impossible to awaken breifly after using IA). True Awakening if actually used in a fight adds a lot of extra power and in some characters cases an almost boss-like presence on the battefield while in this state, this is something that can really turn the fight around. Drive types revolve around teamwork and automatic support, in order to balance not having either IA/True Awakening or UJ/team UJ's anyone using this type can count on automatic support as well as switching support focus during battle, on top of this supports knocked out during the fight may revive after a period of time has passed. The drive type's only trump card is the ability to seal both UJ's and Awakening types abilities for a short period of time.

Also of note, in this iteration of the storm series, customisation has been added, you can now edit your characters looks with accessories as well as their Substitution item and the video that plays upon a successful UJ finisher. Allowing both visual customisation, as well as focus choice really lets someone play how they would want to play, obviously its not the most in-depth customisation system, but it is a very welcome addition to the game.

Adding to this is some new battle mechanics, along with the usual Sub/Guard defence, a counter mechanic and guard break attack have been added, these new mechanics are balanced by their use of resources (reduction of max chakra for counter and ammo system for guard break). With these, and all previous options from the last game, as well as character focus types, present a lot more depth within fights than was seen in storm 3. There are now few more options for both the defending and attacking player, which leads to more interesting fights overall.

Of course, all of this is to speak nothing of the visuals of the game itself. It is quite a beautiful game, the style of the characters is very faithful to the animation style of the anime, and the environments to fight in are just as great to look at as the characters themselves. Add to this the technique animations, including the new awakenings/Special team ultimate jutsu's and this game certainly does not disappoint on the eye candy factor.

I have very few issues with this game, but there were a few things to stick out. Firstly, while the ninja world tournament mode is great, and a fun diversion, the amount of redundant content is a bit too much. There are challanges and 'jobs' on top of recruitment quests for this mode, and while recruitment quests aren't all that bad, there are a LOT of jobs to be done. Case in point, there were at almost 20 jobs for each rank of the tournament I have been in so far, and a vast majority are just the standard 1v1 with supports or the 4v4 orb brawl mode with only one or two being anything different and all of these fights have no real story context. Add to this the challanges of each rank and you have a sizable list of content to get through. The trouble is that it all feels quite repetative after a while, leading to the realisation that the developer added these almost grind like elements mainly for the completionists and to give longevity to what would have otherwise been a short mode.

All in all, here are the pros/cons for this game.

Pros:

New focus types/Customization add to personal choice
Environments and characters are as beautiful as ever
Awakening/UJ/Team UJ animations are awesome
New fight mechanics on top of old help to make the fights more interesting than the last game
Naruto and Sasuke Swapping outfits had me fanboying a little, smart move CC2
Shisui Uchiha and Kurama mode Naruto as playable characters? yespls
Cons:

Lack of longer story content could upset a few fans
Redundant content in the Ninja tournament mode is a little annoying
While I enjoyed the Mecha-Naruto story somewhat, I can see why a lot of people couldn't take his addition to the game seriously
Danzo exists

In summary, this game is better than storm 3, gameplay wise and I suppose graphics wise and is a solid title in itself, but the lack of story content may irk some fans (though it doesn't bother me to much) and the amount of redundant content in the nina world tournament mode may get on the nerves of some completionists.

I give it, 7/10.

reviewText:
If you came here looking for a story, you'll have to turn your head towards last year's Storm 3: Full burst. But this game shines above and beyond the rest of the series in it's mechanics, fun factor and character selection. You can check out my Storm 3 review to see what the game's mechanics are like, as here I'll mostly be stating what's new.

The Ultimate Ninja games have always been all about easy to pick up, yet surprisingly technical combat scenarios that replicate the franchise's most defining elements. The way you play this series has always depended on what kind of character you choose, but now there's even more variety and balance to add into the mix with new ways to use support, and the decision between using Ultimate attacks, awakening mode, or playing defensively with support backing you up and the ability to seal others' attacks.

Where the game lacks in story it makes up for in a new element called World Tournament. For the first time in this series of games, you can take part in 4-person battles, the meat of this mode in where the objective is basically to beat the crap out of everyone and steal their orbs, with the person obtaining the most orbs being the winner after time has elapsed. It's a fun new mode and actually makes some characters who are not so useful in 1v1 situations seem more viable, but it also serves as a way just to have fun and try out each character's abilities. The rest of this World Tournament mode involves running around this new island, fighting against CPUs, unlocking characters, and even fighting the Ghosts" of other players.

Something else new to this game is character customisation. Besides being able to change your character's costume
date: you can also equip accessories on them
hoursPlayed: and even their Ultimate Jutsu finish quotes.\n\nThis is basically Storm 3.5
voteText: and it's for the fans more than anything else
helpfulPercent: but it's a fun game in it's own right and it puts the gameplay front and centre to the experience. It's all about fighting. Whether it's one on one with or without support or World Tournament mode
